section.sectiontext: In this regulation:

definition.def: means a Category I GPS base station validated and categorized by the Provincial government;

means the horizontal and vertical datums as realized on the ground through active control points and geodetic control monuments, including their associated accuracies, defined and published by the Province;
means a claim as defined in the Mineral Tenure Act and includes a placer lease;
means the arithmetic product of the sea level reduction factor and the U.T.M. point scale factor;
means a coordinate control monument as defined in section 11 of the Land Survey Act;
means, with respect to a monument, moved

paragraph.paragraphtext: except by a British Columbia Land Surveyor in the exercise of professional duty, and
in such a way that it can be proven beyond doubt that the disturbed monument was moved from its original position;

definition.def: means a final type control marker officially published on the MASCOT geodetic control database or any other geodetic control monument approved by the Surveyor General;
means determining the coordinates for a point with respect to the adopted British Columbia Geo-Spatial Reference;
means a cadastral survey that has been integrated with a control survey under this regulation;
means an integrated land survey as that term is used in the Land Survey Act;
means a member in good standing of the Corporation of Land Surveyors of the Province of British Columbia;
pertains to all survey posts placed or found shown on a plan tendered for deposit;

means, with respect to a monument, that the position of the monument must be re-established, and can be re-established only by measurements from some other monument or monuments to which the lost monument was previously connected by survey;
means a mineral claim as defined in section 1 of the Mineral Tenure Act;
means North American Datum 1983 (Canadian Spatial Reference System) and is the adopted provincial horizontal datum;

means the absolute accuracy of the coordinates for a point with respect to the adopted British Columbia Geo-Spatial Reference to a 95% confidence level, which is dependent on the network accuracy of the known point(s) used to derive the coordinates of the local survey and the relative accuracy of the connection(s) to the known point(s);

means, with respect to a monument, that the monument is no longer observable but can be restored with confidence from traces remaining on the ground of the original monument or from other physical evidence of the position of the original monument;
means an original monument as defined in section 11 of the Land Survey Act;
means a post described in sections 4 to 9;
means the specifications contained in the current publications regarding control surveys, produced by Geographic Data BC, Ministry of Sustainable Resource Management, Province of British Columbia;
means a reference post described in section 13;
means a timber licence or a special timber licence as defined in section 1 (1) of the Forest Act;
means Universal Transverse Mercator.

section.marginalnote: Duties of a British Columbia land surveyor
section.sectiontext: Each land surveyor must ensure that a legal survey he or she performs, including the plans associated with it, conforms to the requirements of this regulation.

part.parttext: Permanent Survey Monuments and Ancillary Monumentation

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to this regulation, a permanent survey monument must consist of a standard post of a type referred to in sections 4 to 9, together with a reference post of a type referred to in section 12 and, if prescribed, bearing trees, a stone mound or a cairn.
All permanent survey monuments must be manufactured to the design and specifications required by the Surveyor General.

A type 1 post, to be known as the standard concrete post, must consist of a type 2 or type 4 post set in the centre of and flush with the top of a concrete cylinder that is not less than 75 cm high and 30 cm in diameter.
The concrete may be poured into a form or directly into a shaped hole using a form for not less than the top 20 cm.
Not more than 15 cm of the monolith may project above ground level.
A type 2 post, to be known as the standard rock post, must consist of a bronze post cap that is approximately 7.5 cm in diameter and is cast as a unit with a shank that is approximately 6.5 cm long.
A rock post must be securely set into a hole that is drilled in rock or concrete to the full depth of the shank.
A type 3 post, to be known as a lead plug, must consist of lead firmly set into and flush with the top of a hole that is drilled in rock or concrete.
A copper or brass tack must be set in the top of the lead plug to indicate its true position.

A type 4 post, to be known as the standard capped post, must consist of a bronze post cap fitted on a pointed length of steel reinforcing bar that is not less than 15 mm in diameter and not less than 75 cm long.

In loose ground where the surveyor considers that additional stability is required, a stainless steel anchor plate 7.5 cm square with a hole of appropriate size in the centre must be fitted to the post 8 cm above the point and the post must be dug into the ground.

A type 5 post, to be known as the standard iron post, must consist of a galvanized square iron bar that is not less than 1.2 cm across any face nor less than 75 cm long and that has, before galvanizing, been marked near the top with the initials "B.C.L.S.".
A standard iron post must be driven firmly into the ground with not more than 5 cm protruding above ground level.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 6/2004, s. 3.]

An alternate type 5 post, to be known as a short iron post, must consist of a galvanized square iron bar not less than 1.2 cm across any face and not less than 9 cm long, firmly set in a hole drilled in concrete or rock.

The drill hole referred to in subsection (1) must be at least 6 cm deep, and the short iron pin must be securely set with a grout or equivalent compound, or pressure set with lead, and must not extend more than 3 cm above ground level.
Posts of types 1, 2 or 4 must be set with the crown on the cap facing north, and with the centre of the cap, as nearly as possible, at its true position.
The true position must be marked by a small hole that is punched or drilled in the cap.

The surveyor must indicate diagrammatically on the cap the directions of the boundary lines, and the designations of the district lots, sections, blocks and quarters adjoining the corner, together with the year in which the post was set and the registry number of the land surveyor's commission.
Parcel designations under the Land Title Act, other than for roads, railways or rights of way, must not be indicated.
If a post is set as a witness post, the post cap must be marked with the letters "WT" and with the distance and direction to the corner witnessed.

section.sectiontext: The following diagrams illustrate the markings for post caps and Specimen Plans 1 and 2 in Part 9 illustrate the corners represented by the post caps.

subsection.subsectiontext: Each post must be accompanied by a reference post.
Triangular reference posts must comply with the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: measure not less than 8 cm on one face and 5 cm on each of the other faces;
if milled, be chamfered at the top;
if hand hewn, be pointed at the top to shed water;

if referencing a post of type 1, 2 or 4, be at least 1 m high where the post marks a district lot corner, block corner, section corner, centre post or a quarter post and, in every other case, be painted white and be at least 30 cm high, with all posts marked with "MON" on the side facing the post;

if referencing a post of type 3 or 5, be painted white, be at least 30 cm high, and be marked with LP or IP on the side facing the post and with lot or block designations carved or painted on appropriate faces.

subsection.subsectiontext: The metal reference post must consist of an aluminum plate approximately 10 cm by 20 cm, marked "Legal survey post — Do Not Disturb", bolted to a galvanized angle iron post which, if referencing a post of type 1, 2 or 4 at a district lot corner, block corner, section corner, centre post or quarter post, must stand not less than 1 m high and, in every other case, must stand not less than 30 cm high.
Other posts must be approved by the Surveyor General.

section.sectiontext: Where a reference post is set to mark the presence of a post of type 3 or 5 that witnesses a true corner, it must be marked with "WT" and the distance from the post to the true corner.

subsection.subsectiontext: Where bearing trees are required, they must be made and recorded as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: each bearing tree must be blazed and carved with the letters "BT" and the distance to the post;
the distance to the post must be measured from the blaze to a point 1 m vertically above the post;
the diameter and species of the tree and the bearing and distance from the post to the blaze must be recorded and noted on the plan.

subsection.subsectiontext: Bearings may be magnetic or on the same origin as the plan and must be clearly noted.

section.sectiontext: Where posts of type 2 or 4 are placed, and the erection of a standard cairn as defined in section 16 (1) is not required, the surveyor must, if possible, surround the post with a substantial circle of rocks which must be recorded and shown on the plan as a stone mound.

subsection.subsectiontext: At a corner post, a cairn must

paragraph.paragraphtext: be pyramid shaped with the centre of the pyramid lying due south of the post,
have a base with dimensions of 1.5 m and a height of 1 m, and
have one corner adjoining the post.

subsection.subsectiontext: At a witness post, a cairn must

paragraph.paragraphtext: be cone shaped,
have a diameter at the base of 2 m and a height of 1 m, and
stand on the opposite side of the post to the witnessed corner with its centre 1 m from the witness post.

subsection.subsectiontext: Where it is impractical to put the cairn in the place prescribed by subsections (1) and (2), the cairn's location may be varied and the variation must be recorded and shown on the plan.
For new surveys consisting of the surveyor's own work, the minimum accuracy standard expressed as a misclosure must be 1:5000.

If, due to rugged terrain, swamps or other conditions, it is impractical to obtain the minimum accuracy set out in subsection (1), the Surveyor General may, on application, accept a lower standard of accuracy.
Surveys may be conducted using conventional, GPS, or other methods, providing the survey accuracy standards are met.
It is the responsibility of the land surveyor to assess which survey method or combination of survey methods must be used for a particular survey.
The preferred method of placing monuments and determining the length and direction of boundaries is by direct measurement along boundaries.

Survey traverses and networks must consist of closed figures or be confirmed by sufficient redundant measurements to verify the survey accuracy standards required under section 17, except that single measurements may be made when closing between corners of a previously surveyed parcel.
The misclosure to the existing survey must not exceed 1:2 500 ± 0.02 metres, otherwise, the measurements must be independently verified.

Except as permitted by the Surveyor General, measurements shown on the plan must be based on the survey and must not be derived from previously registered plans nor from surveys or plans made by a person other than the surveyor performing the current survey.
The datum for UTM coordinates must be NAD83 (CSRS).
Surveys must be carried out under the on-site supervision of the surveyor signing the plan.
All measuring equipment must be kept in proper adjustment and must be periodically validated to ensure the equipment is operating to the manufacturer's specifications.
The surveyor must keep validation records and be prepared to verify the accuracy of the measuring systems used for any survey project.
A land surveyor must directly assess and manage the method in which the survey measurements are processed and adjusted.
Survey measurement blunders must be detected and eliminated and all known systematic errors must be identified and corrected before adjustment.
Survey measurements must be adjusted to eliminate misclosures.
A least squares adjustment process is the preferred method of adjustment for all surveys and must be used to process redundant post mission GPS measurements.
Bearings may be derived from the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: stellar observations;
solar observations, except for right of way surveys which exceed one kilometre in length;
geodetic control monuments;
GPS derived baselines of a minimum length of 150 metres;
existing surveys for

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: surveys under the Land Act,
surveys under the Land Title Act, except right of way surveys which exceed one kilometre in length, or
surveys under the Strata Property Act;

paragraph.paragraphtext: by other methods if approved by the Surveyor General.

subsection.subsectiontext: Bearings within integrated survey areas must be grid bearings referred to the central meridian of the UTM zone specified on the plan of the appropriate integrated survey area.
Bearings derived by GPS methods or geodetic control monuments must, wherever practical, be grid bearings referred to the central meridian of the UTM zone in which the survey is situated.
Bearings for surveys under Parts 6 to 10 and 13 must be referred to a local astronomic meridian, except those identified in subsections (1) (e) and (f), (2) and (3) of this section.
Bearings for surveys under Part 11 must be referred to the local astronomic meridian.
Bearings for surveys under Part 12 must be

paragraph.paragraphtext: referred to the central meridian of the township in which the survey is situated where the survey lies within the Peace River Block, or
grid bearings referred to the central meridian of the UTM zone in which the survey is situated where the survey lies outside the Peace River Block.

subsection.subsectiontext: Bearings for surveys under Parts 6, 7 and 12 greater than one kilometre in length must be derived as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: at the origin and close of the survey;
at least once

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: for every 40 angles of the main traverse, or
every 8 km along the length of the survey,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the discrepancy between bearings observed under paragraph (b), after convergence has been applied, must not exceed 15 seconds for every kilometre of the extent of the survey.

subsection.subsectiontext: Where any survey is partly within the boundary of an Integrated Survey Area, bearings must be defined according to section 21 (2).

Surveys located outside of integrated survey areas, that are tied to geodetic control monuments or where all or part of the local survey is completed using differential GPS including derivation of bearings, must, if practical, be geo-referenced to the British Columbia geo-spatial reference or other control approved by the Surveyor General.
The estimated network horizontal accuracy under subsection (1) must be less than 2 metres.
Surveys outside of integrated survey areas, other than surveys under subsection (1), may be geo-referenced by autonomous GPS or superior positioning methods.
The position of natural boundaries may be determined by any survey method that yields an accuracy of 0.5 metres or better.
Ties to the natural boundary must be made at intervals sufficiently close to permit the accurate plotting of the natural boundary and the computation of areas.

Where the natural boundary is determined from angular and distance measurements, these ties must be made from a closed traverse line, or by radial ties from points established as part of a closed survey.
The following methods may also be used to determine the present natural boundary upon application and approval by the Surveyor General:

paragraph.paragraphtext: photogrammetric methods where at least two photo points are tied in order to control scale and azimuth and those points must be identified in the photo during the course of the ground survey;
existing suitable maps prepared from photographs where two points common to the map and the survey being conducted can be determined;
other methods approved by the Surveyor General.

subsection.subsectiontext: The plan must be prepared on mylar film with a minimum thickness of 0.075 mm and a matte finish on both sides in one of the following standard sheet sizes:

section.parasandwich: E size — 864 mm by 1120 mm (May be used for plans prepared under the Mineral Tenure Act and the Land Act only, unless approval is given by the registrar).

subsection.subsectiontext: Right of way plans must be prepared using the standard sheet sizes required by subsection (1) if possible but a plan must not in any case exceed 4 metres in length and 0.75 metres in width, except, with the consent of the Surveyor General.
Strata plans must be prepared using an A or B size sheet, unless the Registrar authorizes C or D size plans.
The scale of the plan must be 1:100, 1:125, 1:150, 1:200, 1:250, 1:400, 1:500, 1:600, 1:750 or 1:900, or multiples of such scales by an integral power of 10.
The smallest scale that will permit all required detail and information to be shown on the plan without congestion must be used.
A scale must not be used where a parcel under survey would be represented on the plan as less than 5 cm2.

If the requirements of subsection (3) would result in the preparation of an unduly large plan, the main body of the plan may be drawn to a smaller permitted scale with necessary detail shown on inserted enlargements.

The inserted enlargements referred to in subsection (4) must conform to a scale prescribed by subsection (1) except if impracticable, in which case "not to scale" must be noted on the inserted enlargement.
Plans must be draughted in permanent black ink and all words on the plan, other than signatures, must be printed.
Except in the case of a posting plan and building strata plan, the exterior boundaries of the land being dealt with by the plan must be shown as a solid black line, between 1 and 1.5 mm in width.
If a perimeter boundary is shown on an inserted enlargement, subsection (2) applies to that boundary.
Hatching may be used if it is necessary to distinguish between parcels being surveyed.
The top of the plan must, if practicable, be north and the lettering must be so arranged that it may be easily read when facing the top of the plan.
Extraneous information must not be shown on the plan, however, the name and address of the surveyor's firm may be appended.
Signatures on a plan must be original signatures in black ink.
The style and methods in specimen plans must be used where practicable.
The plan must have a border of solid straight lines.
Plan lettering must be in a solid black font and must not be less than 2.0 mm in height.
Plans must be capable of being reproduced or scanned so that the resulting copy shows a clear and legible image.
The original plan must be identified by adding the word "original" in the lower right hand margin of the plan.
Plans must be in compliance with any standards for electronic submission approved by the Surveyor General.
The plan must contain the following information:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the scale with corresponding bar scale;
a north point;
the derivation of bearings;
a legend giving details of the various monuments shown on the plan, subject to the following:

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the monument standard abbreviations prescribed must be used;
only monuments shown on the plan may be represented in the legend;

paragraph.paragraphtext: the British Columbia Geographic System designation or designations shown immediately below the title using the 6 minute latitude by 12 minute longitude breakdown;
all bearings must be shown in the full circle sexagesimal system clockwise from north;
adjusted bearings and distances must be shown on the plan of survey;

all linear measurements must be shown as horizontal ground level distances in metres and decimals thereof, except for distances to bearing trees and ties to geodetic control monuments or active control points, unless otherwise directed by the Surveyor General;
if a plan shows both horizontal ground level distances and grid distances or only grid distances, a note is required to clearly identify the type of distance shown;
details of found and made bearing trees, stone mounds, cairns or other ancillary evidence;

the boundaries of existing rights of way or easements if there is a charge on title to the parcel under survey or if, in the opinion of the Registrar, there is a reasonable expectation of a charge being placed on the title to the parcel under survey or on the titles of newly created parcels, shown by broken lines;
the boundaries of surveyed covenant areas shown by broken lines;

if the land surveyor considers it appropriate, traverse lines, GPS baselines or radial ties shown as fine broken lines, the dimensions and bearings of which may be shown adjacent to the broken line in the body of the plan or in tabular form at a convenient location on the plan;
the length of the arc and the radius of curved boundary which must be the arc of a circle;
the bearings of radii to intersections with points on the curve;
the bearings of radii at the beginning and end of the curve;
all radii shown as fine broken lines;
the designation of land adjacent to each boundary by the District Lot, lot, block or section number, the land title plan number, or as "Unsurveyed Crown Land", whichever applies;
fine broken lettering to indicate the designations of parcels which will be cancelled on the deposit of the new plan;
areas shown on the plan, except strata floorplans and other unique plans, to the precision given in the following table:
posts found and set;
if an obliterated, lost or disturbed corner post has been reestablished, the method of reestablishment;
if evidence on one side of a road is used to establish the opposite side, sufficient ties by bearing and distance from the posts found to those set on the opposite side;
the perpendicular width of each road created by the survey;
if the sides of the road are not parallel, the varying width clearly indicated;
the names of roads and bodies of water;

the present natural boundary and the natural boundary upon which title is based, except in the case of a plan endorsed under section 94 (1) (d) of the Land Title Act in which case only the present natural boundary must be shown;
the distance along boundaries to the natural boundaries as they exist at the time of the survey;
offsets from a boundary or traverse line to natural boundaries and the distance along the boundary or traverse line to the point of offset;
radial ties to natural boundaries may be shown in tabular format indicating the observation point numbers and their corresponding bearings and distances;
small watercourses of a temporary or seasonal nature that do not have natural boundaries must not be shown on the plan;
the surveyor's certificate in the form prescribed under the Land Title Act Regulation;

the boundaries of all lots, roads and walkways shown by solid black lines, except that, where boundaries have been cancelled or where a block overlaps two or more adjacent sections or District Lots, those boundaries must be shown by broken lines;
natural boundaries shown by a sinuous line;
in a location near the certificate prescribed by paragraph (ff), the following:

section.parasandwich: This plan lies within the............................ Regional District;

paragraph.paragraphtext: where an alternate type 5 post is found or placed, either a note next to the post reading: "short iron post........ [description].........", or an abbreviation of the note in the legend;
post cap diagrams as depicted on specimen plan 1.

subsection.subsectiontext: The plan must contain the following information if applicable:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a statement or diagram of the amount and correct application of convergence between one or more points within the local survey and the central meridian of the UTM zone where grid bearings are used outside of an integrated survey area;
surveys geo-referenced in accordance to section 22 (1) must indicate on the plan the following:

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the datum, UTM coordinates, combined factor, zone and estimated network horizontal accuracy placed next to the geo-referenced point or in a table with a cross reference number where appropriate (the grid bearing and grid distance to geodetic control monuments or active control points may also be shown on the plan);
the notation:

section.subparasandwich: "The UTM coordinates and estimated network horizontal accuracy are derived from ...[Insert Type Of Gps Survey Method].... to ....[Insert Geodetic Control Monument(s) Number(s) And/or Insert Active Control Point(s) Number(s)].....";

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the following note, with modification as necessary:

section.subparasandwich: "This plan shows horizontal ground-level distances based on a mean ellipsoidal elevation of ... [insert elevation] ... metres. To compute grid distances, multiply ground-level distances by the mean combined factor of ... [insert factor] ....";

paragraph.paragraphtext: surveys geo-referenced in accordance with section 22 (3) must indicate on the plan the following:

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the datum, UTM coordinates and zone placed next to the geo-referenced point or in a table with a cross reference number where appropriate;
the notation:

section.subparasandwich: "UTM coordinates are derived by autonomous GPS survey methods.";

paragraph.paragraphtext: if new highways are created, they must be shown on the plan as "road" or "lane" as appropriate.

section.marginalnote: Submission of plans to Surveyor General

subsection.subsectiontext: Plans submitted to the Surveyor General for approval, confirmation, or both, must include the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: appropriate fees;
field notes when requested;
digital plan as specified by the Surveyor General;
a covering letter explaining any deviation from the instructions or this regulation;
the government file number beneath the Surveyor General signature block;
additional requirements for Land Act surveys as follows:

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 6/2004, s. 16 (c).]
final submission of one original mylar and four paper prints;

paragraph.paragraphtext: additional requirements for Land Title Act surveys as follows:

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 6/2004, s. 16 (c).]
final submission of eight paper prints, one original mylar and one duplicate mylar, except railway plans require two duplicate mylars;

paragraph.paragraphtext: additional requirements for Mineral Tenure Act surveys as follows:

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: three preliminary paper prints;
copies of the current records for all mineral titles being surveyed;
copies of the records of all mineral titles which affect, or may affect, the determination of the boundaries of a mineral title being surveyed;

printed forms, obtainable from the Surveyor General, on which the surveyor must record the serial number of each of the identification tags found by the land surveyor as well as all the information found written on the tags or legal post and on the legal corner post or identification posts;
final submission of five paper prints and one original mylar;

paragraph.paragraphtext: for plans under the Petroleum and Natural Gas Act only, a final submission of one original and one paper print.

subsection.subsectiontext: If complete posting of a survey is impractical, application may be made to the Surveyor General for modified posting.
The application must be in writing and include a detailed explanation why posting is impractical and a sketch indicating the proposed modified posting.
If an application for modified posting is approved, the following note must be shown on the plan:

section.subsandwich: The monumentation on this survey is approved ..............[Date]

part.parttext: Control Surveys in Integrated Survey Areas

section.sectiontext: In this Part, control survey means a survey to establish coordinates for

paragraph.paragraphtext: a control monument set before constituting a portion of British Columbia as an integrated survey area, or
an additional control monument or more accurate coordinates for an existing control monument in a constituted integrated survey area.

section.sectiontext: This Part applies to all control surveys in an integrated survey area.

subsection.subsectiontext: The Surveyor General will issue survey instructions for integrated control surveys to a British Columbia Land Surveyor.
Control survey instructions outline specific horizontal and vertical accuracy standards and submission requirements.
A control survey must be integrated with the Provincial and Federal Geodetic (Survey Control) Networks.
Coordinates must be based on the North American Datum approved by the Surveyor General.
Elevations must be referred to the vertical datum approved by the Surveyor General.
A control monument may be set at a position that is arbitrary in relation to original monuments.
If an original monument complies with the requirements of sections 36 and 37, the surveyor may upgrade it to the status of a control monument.
If an original monument does not comply with the requirements of sections 36 and 37, the surveyor may replace it with a control monument.

section.sectiontext: Before the constituting of an integrated survey area, control monuments must be established in or surrounding the area to a density approved by the Surveyor General.

A control monument must be a type 1 or type 2 post prescribed in Part 1 of this regulation, a special survey monument as defined in section 322 of the Land Title Act, or a type of monument approved by the Surveyor General.
A control monument must be set in a safe location and in a useful position such that it is least likely to be subject to damage or removal or create interference.

subsection.subsectiontext: Control monuments in rural areas must be referenced by reference posts referred to in section 12 or bearing trees referred to in section 14.
A reference post or bearing tree must not be used as a means of replacing a monument that has been damaged or removed.
The post cap of a control monument must be marked with a unique identifier or other designation allotted to it by the Surveyor General.
If an original monument is upgraded to the status of control monument, the markings designated under subsection (1) must be added to the post cap.

section.sectiontext: A plan of an integrated survey area must be prepared and must show all of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the number and other designation of the integrated survey area, a legend, the name of the regional district and the British Columbia Geographic System designation or designations;
the number and year of approval of the order of the Lieutenant Governor in Council that constituted the integrated survey area;
sufficient planimetric detail to indicate the location of control monuments;
the boundaries of the integrated survey area;
the location of control monuments by the symbol prescribed in section 29 (1), accompanied by the unique identifier or designation allotted under section 43;
details of the projection used, the origin of coordinates, the datum used and the scale of the plan;
the geographical graticule by fiducial marks at suitable intervals in the margin of the plan;
the rectangular grid, by marking grid intersections at suitable intervals across the face of the plan.

section.sectiontext: A certificate, which is considered to be a part of the plan, must be appended to the plan and must show all of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the number and other designation of the integrated survey area;
the year of approval and number that constitutes the integrated survey area;
projection, origin and datum for rectangular coordinates;
date of issue, consolidation or revision of the certificate;
the UTM coordinates of control monuments;
the point combined factor for each monument;
disturbed monuments identified and listed, together with the original and revised UTM coordinates, point combined factor and the date of revision of the coordinates;
destroyed monuments identified and listed, together with their U.T.M. coordinates, point combined factor and the date of their destruction, if known;
the elevation of each control monument.

section.sectiontext: The original plan must be filed in the office of the Surveyor General and a copy is to be filed in the land title office of the district.

division.divisiontext:
Correcting, Amending and Adding Coordinates of
Control Monuments to the Plan

subsection.subsectiontext: If a control monument coordinate error is brought to the attention of the Surveyor General and a survey is made under his or her direction to establish the correct coordinates, or if additional surveys to establish more accurate coordinates for control monuments are made in an integrated survey area under the direction of the Surveyor General, new coordinates may be computed.
If the Surveyor General deems it necessary, readjustment of an integrated survey may be carried out in order to maintain the integrity of the survey fabric.

section.sectiontext: If new control monuments are established or coordinates of control monuments are amended or corrected, the Surveyor General must file, in the land title office of the district, a supplementary certificate setting out the new or amended coordinates, which, on filing, become the official coordinates of the monuments concerned.
The Surveyor General is responsible for updating and revising plans of integrated survey areas.

part.parttext: Legal Surveys in Integrated Survey Areas

section.sectiontext: In this Part, monument means a type 1 or type 2 standard post prescribed by Part 1 of this regulation.

subsection.subsectiontext: This Part applies to all legal surveys in integrated survey areas.
If an area to be surveyed lies partially within an integrated survey area, this Part applies to the whole survey.
If there is a conflict between this Part and another Part, this Part prevails.

section.sectiontext: It is the responsibility of every land surveyor to determine whether a legal survey he or she conducts relates to land within an integrated survey area.

subsection.subsectiontext: Legal surveys must be integrated with active or passive geodetic control monuments in the vicinity of the area under survey.
Integration of legal surveys means performing one of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a conventional closed traverse containing any two intervisible passive control monuments;
a conventional traverse closing on two pairs of intervisible passive control monuments;
ties to two or more passive or active control monuments;
two independent ties to one active control monument.

subsection.subsectiontext: Integration of legal surveys by conventional methods must meet or exceed the survey accuracy standards required under section 17.
Integration of legal surveys to active control points must meet or exceed an accuracy of 0.05 metres.

If a legal survey is integrated to an active control point and the survey is within 200 metres of one or more passive control monuments, a tie should be made to at least one of the nearby passive control monuments.
Conventional bearing misclosures between published geodetic control monument lines must not exceed 20 times the square root of n, where n is the number of angles in the closing traverse.

The Surveyor General may exempt a surveyor from any provision of this regulation, in whole or in part, if, in the opinion of the Surveyor General, strict compliance is impracticable, and the surveyor, before completion of the survey, explains in writing why the survey cannot be completed in strict compliance with this regulation.
Applications for exemption for integration under section 49 will be considered if

paragraph.paragraphtext: more than three traverse hubs would be required to tie to the integrated control monuments, or
a conventional traverse to the integrated control monuments will exceed 1 000 metres.

subsection.subsectiontext: New right of way, posting, strata or reference plans wholly within a plan or plans previously integrated under section 49 do not have to comply with section 49, and a certificate issued under section 52 (4) is not required.

section.marginalnote: Damaged or destroyed control monument — report
section.sectiontext: If a control monument is damaged or destroyed, the surveyor must promptly report the matter to the Surveyor General.

subsection.subsectiontext: Plans within integrated survey areas must contain the following information:

paragraph.paragraphtext: if integration under section 49 is completed solely by conventional means, the plan must show at least two or more geodetic control monuments accompanied by connecting data to all original monuments so that the coordinates of any monument or position shown on the plan may be computed without reference to any other plan;
if integration under section 49 is completed by ties to passive or active geodetic control monuments, the plan must show

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the location of two or more geodetic control monuments relative to the local survey, and
the location of the active control points relative to the local survey by indicating the grid bearing and grid distance to the active control point(s);

paragraph.paragraphtext: if integration under section 49 is completed solely by ties to active control point(s), the plan must show the location of the active control point(s) relative to the local survey by indicating the grid bearing and grid distance to the active control point(s);
the Integrated Survey Area number, name, datum, bearing derivation and adopted combined factor, and must contain the following notations:

section.subparasandwich: Grid bearings are derived from ...... [observations between geodetic control monument(s) or GPS observations]................
This plan shows horizontal ground-level distances except where otherwise noted. To compute grid distances, multiply ground-level distances by combined factor .......... .

subsection.subsectiontext: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 6/2004, s. 21.]
Control monuments found must be shown on the plan of survey by the symbol prescribed in section 29 (1), together with the number or designation of each control monument.
If exemption from integration is granted under section 50, the plan must contain the following notation:

section.subsandwich: Pursuant to section 50 of the General Survey Instruction Regulation, this survey need not be integrated with survey control.

section.sectiontext: In this Part:

definition.def: means a forest service road as defined in the Forest Act;
means a highway as defined in the Highway Act or a public road as defined in the Land Act;
includes a statutory right of way under the Land Title Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (2), a survey under this Part must not be posted until clearing has been completed.
The survey of a pipeline right of way must not be posted until construction has been completed.
The survey of a right of way must be completed in accordance with section 24 of the Pipeline Act.

A right of way that crosses a surveyed parcel of land, or a surveyed road or right of way, must be tied, by bearing and distance, to at least one monument of the existing survey on each side of the right of way.
If subsection (1) cannot be complied with, other ties must be made to determine the true position of the intersected boundary.
If a right of way crosses an area covered by a timber licence, a surveyor must ascertain whether the licence is in force.
The area covered by a timber licence that is not in force need not be tied.
The area covered by a timber licence in force must be tied

paragraph.paragraphtext: in the manner provided for in section 55 if the area has been assigned a district lot number and surveyed under the Land Act or an Act which that Act replaced, or
in any other case, in a manner sufficient to enable the boundaries of the licence to be indicated on the plan without dimensions.

subsection.subsectiontext: In complying with subsection (3) (b), a reference to cut lines, topography, other survey plans or a tie to one corner is sufficient.

section.marginalnote: Crossing of water features (unsurveyed Crown land)
section.sectiontext: If a right of way, through unsurveyed Crown land, crosses a lake, stream, river or tidal water, the natural boundaries must be tied in accordance with section 23.
If a right of way under survey, through a surveyed parcel or a parcel existing by description, crosses a lake, stream, river or tidal water, the natural boundaries must

paragraph.paragraphtext: be tied in accordance with section 23, and,
where the natural boundary differs with the title boundary of the upland parcel, enough survey evidence must be tied in order to resolve the discrepancy under section 118 of the Land Title Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: Public roads must be excluded from a right of way and, if unsurveyed, the width to be excluded must be

paragraph.paragraphtext: in the case of a road established by notice in the Gazette, the width stated in the notice,
in the case of a road established under section 4 of the Highway Act, the travelled width,
in the case of a road established under section 79 of the Land Act, the width shown on the plan which established the road, and

in the case of a road or trail referred to in section 27 (b) of the Land Act, the width required by section 13 or 57 of the Land Act, or if section 13 or 57 does not apply, the improved width or travelled width, whichever is greater.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a right of way over Crown land crosses an unsurveyed travelled road, other than a public road, the road must be shown on the plan as part of the right of way without reference to its width.
If a right of way crosses a Forest Service Road, the road must be shown as part of the right of way.

section.marginalnote: Crossing mineral claims and 2 post claims

subsection.subsectiontext: A right of way that crosses a 2 post claim in respect of which a Crown grant of the surface has been made must be tied in accordance with section 55.
A right of way that crosses an isolated 2 post claim or an isolated mineral claim

paragraph.paragraphtext: in respect of which a Crown grant of the surface has not been made, and
that has been surveyed,

section.subsandwich: must be tied to 2 monuments of that survey or of another survey to which the claim has been tied, and intersections with all boundaries of the claim must be calculated and indicated on the plan using the dimensions on the existing survey.

subsection.subsectiontext: A right of way that crosses 2 or more 2 post claims or mineral claims

paragraph.paragraphtext: in respect of which a Crown grant of the surface has not been made,
which have been surveyed, and
which are contiguous to one another,

section.subsandwich: must be tied to any 2 monuments of the surveys of these claims, and intersections with all boundaries of the claims must be calculated and indicated on the plan using the dimensions on the existing survey.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a right of way referred to in subsection (3) exceeds 1.5 km in length over those claims, there must be one tie in accordance with subsection (3) every 1.5 km.
The area of a right of way that crosses a mineral claim or 2 post claim must be shown on the plan.

section.sectiontext: Intersections of a right of way with

paragraph.paragraphtext: boundaries that exist by description under the Land Title Act,
lines that bound unposted aliquot parts of surveyed parcels, or
unposted legal subdivision boundaries within the township system,

section.subsandwich: must be calculated and shown on the plan and need not be posted.

section.sectiontext: Except as provided in this Division, posts of type 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5 must be set as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: where the right of way begins;
where the right of way ends;
at each angle of the right of way;
where the right of way intersects with an existing surveyed boundary;
on both sides of a road referred to in section 59;
at or near where the right of way intersects with a natural boundary of a body of water having a width greater than 6 metres;
at a point witnessing a location referred to in paragraphs (a) to (e).

subsection.subsectiontext: Posts of type 1, 2 or 4 must be set on one side of the right of way at intersections with district lot, section or quarter section boundaries and at intervals along the right of way not greater than 1 km.
If the length of a right of way crossing a body of water exceeds 500 m, a type 1, 2 or 4 post must be set on one boundary near the intersection with the natural boundary.
Posts of types 1, 2 and 4 must be numbered consecutively along the right of way and the designation of adjoining parcels must be marked on the posts.

section.marginalnote: Narrow rights of way and rough country

subsection.subsectiontext: If a right of way has a width of 6 m or less it may be posted on one boundary only.
If a right of way crosses extremely rough country, the Surveyor General may, on application, permit posting on one boundary, along the centreline or on a suitable offset.

section.marginalnote: Right of way adjoining an existing right of way
section.sectiontext: If a new right of way is coincident with and parallel to an existing right of way and the owners of the right of way are the same, the surveyor may

subsection.subsectiontext: post both sides of the new right of way, or
post the outermost boundaries of the new and the existing right of way.

section.sectiontext: If a right of way intersects with the boundaries of an area covered by a timber licence other than an area referred to in section 56 (3) (a), posts need not be set.

section.marginalnote: Replacement of posts at district lot or section corners

subsection.subsectiontext: If, in the course of a survey, a district lot corner, section corner, centre post or quarter post is tied to, and is not found monumented with, a post of type 1, 2 or 4, or an old style Dominion iron post, it must be replaced with a post of type 1, 2 or 4.

If no evidence of an original district lot corner, section corner, centre post or quarter post is found, the position of the original post must be reestablished from other evidence in accordance with the Land Survey Act and posted with a post of type 1, 2 or 4.

section.marginalnote: Railway Belt and the Peace River Block

subsection.subsectiontext: The following applies if a right of way crosses land in the Railway Belt or the Peace River Block:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a dotted line on an official township plan may be treated as a line that exists by description, and confirmation of the cadastral fabric should be obtained from the Surveyor General;
if a theoretical division of a section into quarters or quarters into legal subdivisions is not shown on the official township plan, theoretical division must not be shown on the right of way plan.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a division by description referred to in section 61 (a) has been registered in respect of land referred to in subsection (1), section 61 applies and the parcel must be shown on the plan.

section.marginalnote: Mineral claim and 2 post claim boundaries

subsection.subsectiontext: If a right of way intersects a 2 post mineral claim in respect of which a Crown grant of the surface has been made, posts must be set at all points of intersection.
If a tie has been made under section 60 (2), (3) or (4), the boundary of the mineral claims or 2 post claims must be posted where the right of way enters and exits the claims.
On application, the Surveyor General may permit modified posting.

section.sectiontext: General right of way plans must contain the following information in addition to Part 3 if appropriate:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the width of the right of way at frequent intervals;
the values of convergence from the origin to points on the plan at 8 kilometre intervals or less;
the serial numbers that have been stamped on the monuments;

a book of reference, if the plan deals with more than one parcel, near the title, listing in progressive order the legal description of all parcels crossed by the right of way and the total area of right of way within each parcel;
the plan title placed at the right hand end of the plan indicating the locality and land district in which the right of way is located;

if a timber licence has a licence number and a district lot number and no survey has been completed under the Land Act in respect of the land covered by the timber licence, both the licence number and district lot number must be shown with equal prominence on the plan;
if a survey under the Land Act was carried out in respect of land covered by a timber licence, only the district lot number must be shown;
surveyed and unsurveyed forest service roads should be included within the right of way and labelled surveyed or unsurveyed forest service road as appropriate;
if a right of way is divided by a road, the plan must show ties across the road in fine broken lines and must provide a mathematical link across the road;
if private lands are dealt with and the natural boundary differs from the title boundary, the surveyor must proceed under section 118 (1) of the Land Title Act.

section.marginalnote: General right of way plans crossing both Crown and private land

subsection.subsectiontext: If a right of way crosses both Crown land and private land, a separate plan must be prepared in respect of the part of the right of way that crosses Crown land.
All plans over Crown land must be submitted to the Surveyor General and must include the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: appropriate fees;
cover letter explaining any deviation from the general survey instructions;
two preliminary prints;
final submission of eight paper prints, one original mylar and one duplicate mylar;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 6/2004, s. 24 (b).]
the following notation:

section.subsandwich: I hereby certify that this is the Official Plan of the right of way shown outlined hereon.
section.parasandwich: placed in the bottom right-hand corner of the plan.

section.sectiontext: In this Part:

definition.def: means a District Highways Manager of the Ministry of Transportation;
means a highway as defined in the Highway Act or a forest service road as defined in the Forest Act;
means a railway within the meaning of the Railway Act and includes

paragraph.paragraphtext: a railway established under an enactment of another jurisdiction that provides for a railway in British Columbia, and
a railway right of way;

definition.def: means a surveyed or unsurveyed public road which is not under survey.

section.sectiontext: Before commencing a railway survey that crosses Crown land, the surveyor must obtain parcel designations from the Surveyor General.

subsection.subsectiontext: Widenings of highways or railways on Crown land must, if practicable, be bounded by a series of straight lines.

Widenings of highways or railways on land other than Crown land must be surveyed to conform as closely as practicable to the boundaries shown on the design plans or as described in instructions provided by the appropriate authority.

Construction widths or other conditions that differ from those provided on the plans or described in the instructions must be reported to the appropriate authority, and that authority must provide further instructions.

section.sectiontext: The use of the spiral-circular-spiral curve used in highway or railway construction must be replaced by one circular curve of a radius which will reduce the displacement of the centreline of the constructed road or railway from the centreline of the highway or railway under survey to a minimum, or terminal curves must be used in place of the spiral curves.
The boundaries of a highway or railway should be surveyed symmetrically with the centre line of the constructed highway or railway.

subsection.subsectiontext: A highway or railway under survey that crosses a boundary of a surveyed parcel of land or a surveyed road or right of way must be tied, by bearing and distance, to at least one monument of the existing boundary on each side of the highway or railway.
If subsection (1) cannot be complied with, other ties must be made to determine the true position of the intersected boundary.

section.sectiontext: Timber licence boundaries must be surveyed in accordance with section 56.
Ties to water features must be in accordance with sections 57 and 58.

subsection.subsectiontext: A highway or railway under survey that crosses a mineral claim in respect of which a Crown grant of the surface has been made must be tied in accordance with section 77.

A highway or railway under survey that crosses an isolated mineral claim in respect of which a Crown grant of the surface has not been made, and that has been surveyed, must be tied to 2 monuments of that survey or of another survey to which the mineral claim has been tied and intersections with all boundaries of the mineral claim must be calculated and indicated on the plan using the dimensions on the existing survey.

A highway or railway under survey that crosses 2 or more mineral claims in respect of which a Crown grant of the surface has not been made, which have been surveyed and which are contiguous to one another, must be tied to any 2 monuments of the surveys of these mineral claims, and intersections with all boundaries of the mineral claims must be calculated and indicated on the plan using the dimensions on the existing survey.
If a highway or railway under survey referred to in subsection (3) exceeds 1.5 km in length over those mineral claims, there must be one tie in accordance with subsection (3) every 1.5 km.
The area of a highway or railway under survey crossing a mineral claim must be shown on the plan.

section.sectiontext: If the highway or railway under survey and an unsurveyed road both cross the same surveyed lands and plans of those lands have been deposited in a land title office, the first course from a junction of the road that joins the highway or railway must be tied.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (2), the boundary system described in section 83 must be used in all highway or railway surveys.
If it is impracticable to use the boundary system, the centre line system described in section 84 may be used, with the prior approval of the Surveyor General.
Type 4 posts must be set on one side of the highway or railway under survey

paragraph.paragraphtext: at points of curve,
at points of deflection,
at intermediate points on tangent, so that the distance between the posts is no greater than 1 km, and
at points of intersection with boundaries of

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a district lot other than mineral claims,
a section,
a block, and
a mineral claim if the surface rights have been Crown granted,

section.subsandwich: and must be the main monumentation of the boundary system of monumentation.

subsection.subsectiontext: Type 5 posts must be set

paragraph.paragraphtext: on the side of the highway or railway under survey opposite the side posted with the main monumentation, and
on both sides of the highway or railway under survey at intersections

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: with any type of surveyed boundary not referred to in subsection (1) (d), and
with unsurveyed described boundaries.

subsection.subsectiontext: Type 4 posts must be set

paragraph.paragraphtext: at centre line points of intersection, or at points witnessing centre line points of intersection on subtangents or subtangents produced,
at intermediate points on the boundary of the highway or railway under survey, if any tangent exceeds 1 km in length, and
at points of intersection between one highway or railway boundary and boundaries of

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a district lot other than mineral claims,
a section,
a block, and
a mineral claim if the surface rights have been Crown granted,

section.subsandwich: and must be the main monumentation of the centre line system of monumentation.

subsection.subsectiontext: Type 4 posts required by this section must not be set

paragraph.paragraphtext: on the shoulder of the highway or railway under survey,
in ditches adjacent to the highway or railway under survey, or
in any place where they may be disturbed by highway or railway maintenance equipment.

subsection.subsectiontext: Type 5 posts must be set on the boundary of the highway or railway under survey

paragraph.paragraphtext: at all points of curve and deflection,
on the side of the highway or railway under survey opposite the side posted with the main monumentation at intersections with the boundaries referred to in subsection (1) (c), and
on both sides of the highway or railway under survey at intersections

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: with any type of surveyed boundary not referred to in subsection (1) (c), and
with unsurveyed described boundaries.

section.sectiontext: In the boundary system and in the centre line system

paragraph.paragraphtext: type 1 or 2 posts must be substituted for type 4 posts so as to give an average density of one type 1 or 2 post every 2 km, and
type 5 posts may be substituted for type 1, 2 or 4 posts so as to reduce the average density of type 1, 2 or 4 posts to 5 per kilometre.

section.sectiontext: Points of intersection of the highway or railway under survey with district lot, section and block boundaries that are no longer parcel boundaries need not be posted but must be indicated on the plan without dimensions.

section.marginalnote: Mineral claim and 2 post claim boundaries

subsection.subsectiontext: If a tie has been made under section 80 (2), (3) or (4), the boundary of the mineral claims or 2 post claims must be posted where the highway or railway enters and exits the claims.
On application, the Surveyor General may permit modified posting.
If, due to interference by fences and other structures, posting under this Division is impracticable, posts must be offset toward the centre of the highway or railway.
If practicable, posts that are offset must be set

paragraph.paragraphtext: at a point on the production of an intersecting boundary,
on the radial line at a point of curve, or
on the bisector of an angle at a deflection point.

section.marginalnote: Replacement of posts at district lot or section corners

subsection.subsectiontext: If, in the course of a survey, a district lot corner, section corner, centre post or quarter post is tied to, and is not found monumented with, a post of type 1, 2 or 4 or an old style Dominion iron post, it must be replaced with a post of type 1, 2 or 4.

If no evidence of an original district lot corner, section corner, centre post or quarter post is found, the position of the original post must be reestablished from other evidence in accordance with the Land Survey Act and posted with a post of type 1, 2 or 4.

section.marginalnote: Railway Belt and the Peace River Block
section.sectiontext: If a highway or railway under survey crosses land in the Railway Belt or the Peace River Block, the survey must be conducted in accordance with section 68.

subsection.subsectiontext: Monuments must be marked with the designation of lands adjoining the highway or railway.
Posts of types 1, 2 and 4 that are not sited to mark intersections with the boundaries of a district lot, section or block must be serially numbered.
If posts are set to mark changes in direction of highway or railway boundaries, the abbreviations in subsection (5) must be used.
If a railway under survey over Crown land has been given a district lot number or a block designation, posts must be marked accordingly.
In marking post caps, the following abbreviations apply:

paragraph.paragraphtext: "PC" means the point of curve;
"POT" means the point on tangent, subtangent or subtangent produced;
"PI" means point of intersection;
"R" means the highway under survey;
"RR" means the railway under survey.

section.sectiontext: This Division applies only to the survey of a highway as defined in section 72.

If future construction renders a fully posted survey impractical, the highway under survey must be referenced by monuments before construction and then posted after construction has been completed in accordance with section 69 of the Land Title Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: A control traverse must be established in a suitable location, to be determined by the land surveyor, and must be referenced by monuments of type 1, 2 or 4.
The control traverse plan must be submitted to the Surveyor General for deposit into the Crown Land Registry.

section.sectiontext: All ties, as required by section 77, and replacement of corners, as required by section 89, must be carried out, but the posting of the boundaries of the highway under survey must not be carried out until all construction has been completed.

subsection.subsectiontext: Plans defining the highway required must be prepared and submitted to the Surveyor General for approval.
Block outline surveys need not comply with sections 82 to 85 inclusive.

section.sectiontext: At the time of submission of block outline plans to the Surveyor General for approval, the ministry submitting the plan will be required to submit a letter from the land surveyor stating that he or she will guarantee completion of posting in accordance with the terms of the order.

subsection.subsectiontext: After construction has been completed, final posting as required by Division 4 of this Part must be carried out.
The Surveyor General may grant an extension of time in which to complete the posting.

section.sectiontext: Monuments of type 1, 2 or 4, set to reference the control traverse, may be included in the average density calculations for substitution purposes, as outlined in sections 83, 84 and 85, providing those monuments remain undisturbed.

section.marginalnote: Additional highway and railway plan requirements
section.sectiontext: A plan of a highway or railway must contain the following information in addition to that required by Part 3:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the width of the highway or railway at frequent intervals;
the values of convergence from the origin to points on the plan at 8 kilometre intervals or less;
the serial numbers that have been stamped on the monuments;

a book of reference, if the plan deals with more than one parcel, near the title, listing in progressive order the legal description of all parcels crossed by the highway or railway and the total area of highway or railway within each parcel;
the plan title placed at the right hand end of the plan indicating the location and land district in which the highway or railway is located;
both Crown and private land may be dealt with on a plan of a highway survey, however, separate plans are required for railway surveys;

if a timber licence has a licence number and a district lot number and no survey has been completed under the Land Act in respect of the land covered by the timber licence, both the licence number and district lot number must be shown with equal prominence on the plan;
if a survey under the Land Act was carried out in respect of land covered by a timber licence, only the district lot number must be shown;
the Surveyor General should be contacted regarding appropriate notations for highway plans over Crown land;
(i) the following notation is required for railway and highway plans over titled or untitled Crown land:

tablerow.tablecol:
Official Plan
CONFIRMED UNDER SECTION 72
Land Act
_____________________________
Surveyor General
Victoria, B.C.___________________

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the following notation is also required for railway plans:

section.subparasandwich: I hereby certify that this is the Official Plan of

section.marginalnote: Existing roads through surveyed lands (highway plans)
section.sectiontext: If a highway under survey and an unsurveyed road both cross the same surveyed lands, and plans of those lands have been deposited in a land title office, the highway plan must show

paragraph.paragraphtext: without dimensions, that part of the road contained in whole or in part within the highway boundaries,
without dimensions, the first course from a junction of the road that joins the highway, and

on the face of the plan, the area of existing roads made public by section 4 of the Highway Act or by notice in the Gazette, the area of the new road being acquired and the total area of the road within the highway boundaries.

section.marginalnote: Existing roads through Crown lands (highway plans)
section.sectiontext: If the highway under survey and an unsurveyed road both cross unsurveyed lands or Crown lands of the district lot, section or sub-lot category, the plans of which have not been deposited in a land title office, the plan of the highway under survey must show

paragraph.paragraphtext: by dotted lines, the travelled surface of the road departing from the highway, and
no part of the road contained within the highway boundaries.

subsection.subsectiontext: Public roads must be excluded from a railway and, if unsurveyed, the width to be excluded must be

paragraph.paragraphtext: in the case of a road established by notice in the Gazette, the width stated in the notice,
in the case of a road established under section 4 of the Highway Act the travelled width,
in the case of a road established under section 80 of the Land Act, the width shown on the plan which established the road, and
in the case of a road or trail referred to in section 27 (b) of the Land Act, the width required by section 13 or 57 of the Land Act or, if section 13 or 57 does not apply, the travelled width.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a railway over Crown land crosses an unsurveyed travelled road, other than a public road, the road must be shown on the plan as part of the right of way without reference to its width.

section.sectiontext: A railway survey crossing Crown land must be registered in accordance with the Land Title Act.

part.parttext:
Surveys of Land in the Esquimalt and
Nanaimo Railway Grant

section.sectiontext: In this Part, Act means the Land Title Act.
This Part applies to the conduct of surveys and the preparation of explanatory plans under section 70 of the Act.
A surveyor must apply to the Surveyor General for approval of the proposed method of preparation of plans that are referred to in section 70 (1) and (2) of the Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: The applications referred to in section 70 (1) and (2) of the Act must be accompanied by all of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a paper print of a cut sheet of an appropriate part of a map of the area bearing the number of the map from which it is taken;
a print of the plan of each of the surveyed blocks that surround the area dealt with in the proposed plan;

if the perimeter of the area dealt with by the survey is completely dimensioned, a traverse sheet or computer output sheet showing complete data of boundary courses as they appear on previously deposited plans, and the error of closure;
a statement indicating ownership of surveyed and unsurveyed surrounding blocks.

subsection.subsectiontext: The block that is to be surveyed must be outlined on the print of the cut sheet in heavy outline along previously surveyed lines and by a different line along the new boundary, and the area outlined must be the same as the area shown on the plan attached to the agreement between the Esquimalt and Nanaimo Railway Company and the purchaser.

section.marginalnote: Plans under section 70 (1) of the Act
section.sectiontext: Approval of applications of plans prepared under section 70 (1) of the Act is unconditional.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (2), the approval according to section 70 (2) of the Act is conditional on obtaining a closure with a limit of error not exceeding 1:2 500 ± 2 cm, after the unsurveyed boundaries of the area are run or traversed.
The Surveyor General may, in special circumstances, permit an error of closure that does not comply with subsection (1).
Adjustment of bearings must not be made unless the course being adjusted has been tied on the ground.
Bearings of successive boundaries of a block must not be adjusted on the basis of a tie to only one course.
An explanation must be given to the Surveyor General when any adjustment to bearings has been made.

section.sectiontext: Deviations between a boundary set out in an application approved by the Surveyor General and the same boundary as it has been surveyed under section 70 (2) of the Act must be reported to the Surveyor General when the completed plan is submitted for approval under section 70 (3) of the Act.

division.divisiontext:
Block Outline Surveys of Land in the Esquimalt
and Nanaimo Railway Grant

section.sectiontext: This Division applies to block outline surveys of land in the Esquimalt and Nanaimo Railway Grant.
An application under section 69 (1) of the Act must be accompanied by all of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: 2 paper prints of the proposed survey;
a proposal of the plan of posting and the method of survey;
a statement indicating ownership of the surrounding blocks;
a statement indicating whether it will be a complete survey or a survey made under section 70 (2) of the Act.

section.sectiontext: A corner that cannot be marked by a post of type 3, 4 or 5 must be witnessed by a post of type 1 or 2.

subsection.subsectiontext: A witness post must be set so that

paragraph.paragraphtext: it is intervisible with at least one other witness post, control monument or provincial triangulation station,
intervisibility is unlikely to be impaired by new timber growth, and
if practicable, it will not be subject to disturbance by logging operations.

subsection.subsectiontext: If maintenance of intervisibility may be disrupted by timber growth, additional posts must be set to achieve compliance with subsection (1) and to allow for future bearing derivation.

section.sectiontext: A witness post must, if possible, be referenced by at least 3 bearing trees and a cairn.

Every witness post and every corner being surveyed must be coordinated on a rectangular coordinate system and the plan must include the coordinates of no fewer than 2 corners of an adjoining previous survey.
The survey must be geo-referenced to geodetic control monuments in the vicinity or to active control point(s) to the accuracy stated in section 22 (2).

subsection.subsectiontext: A post that witnesses a corner must not be set more than 400 m from that corner and a post or pairs of posts must not witness more than 3 corners.
Witness posts must be clearly marked with the letters "Wt" and a serial number that must be shown on the plan.

section.sectiontext: Boundaries of the block being surveyed under the block outline method need not be run nor blazed.

If a block outline survey has been consented to of an unsurveyed area designated as a block in an original grant from the E & N Railway Company under section 70 (2) of the Act, it must contain the following notation:
